'''Cimicidae''' (or sometimes '''bedbugs''') are small [[parasitic]] insects. The most common type is ''Cimex lectularius''.<ref name=NEJM2009>{{cite journal |author=Goddard J, deShazo R|title=Bed bugs (Cimex lectularius) and clinical consequences of their bites |journal=JAMA |volume=301 |issue=13 |pages=1358â66|year=2009 |month=April |pmid=19336711 |doi=10.1001/jama.2009.405 |url=}}</ref> The term usually refers to species that prefer to feed on human [[blood]]. All insects in this family live by feeding exclusively on the blood of [[homeothermic|warm-blooded]] animals.<ref name=bioofbedbug> {{Cite journal |last1 = Reinhardt | first1 = Klaus | last2 = Siva-Jothy| first2 = Michael T.| title = Biology of the Bed Bugs (Cimicidae) |journal = [[Annual Review of Entomology]] |volume = 52 | pages = 351â374 | publisher = | location = |month= Jan |pmid = 16968204 | year=2007 |url = http://www.falw.vu.nl/nl/Images/siva%202006_tcm19-30750.pdf |doi = 10.1146/annurev.ento.52.040306.133913 |accessdate = 26 May 2010 }} </ref><ref name=mednewstoday/>
A number of health effects may occur due to bed bugs, including [[skin rashes]], psychological effects, and allergic symptoms. Diagnosis involves both finding bed bugs and the occurrence of compatible symptoms. Treatment is otherwise symptomatic.
In the [[developed world]], bed bugs were largely eradicated as pests in the early 1940s, but have increased in prevalence since about 1995.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1 = Kilpenen | first1 = O. |last2 = Vagn Jensen | first2 = K-M. |last3 = Kristensen | first3 = M. |title = Bed Bug Problems in Denmark, with a European Perspective |pages = 395â399 |url = http://www.icup.org.uk/reports/ICUP858.pdf |accessdate = 27 May 2010 }}{{Cite book |last1 = Robinson | first1 = WH | last2 = Bajomi | first2 = D. (eds) |title = Proceedings of the Sixth International Conference on Urban Pests |publisher = OOK-Press Kft | year = 2008| location = Hungary }} </ref> Because infestation of human habitats has been on the increase, bed bug bites and related conditions have been on the rise as well.<ref name=JAMA2009/><ref name=Kolb2009>{{cite journal |author=Kolb A, Needham GR, Neyman KM, High WA |title=Bedbugs |journal=Dermatol Ther |volume=22 |issue=4 |pages=347â52 |year=2009 |pmid=19580578 |doi=10.1111/j.1529-8019.2009.01246.x |url=}}</ref> The exact causes of this resurgence remain unclear; it is variously ascribed to greater foreign travel, more frequent exchange of second-hand furnishings among homes, a greater focus on control of other pests resulting in neglect of bed bug countermeasures, and increasing resistance to pesticides.<ref name=Kolb2009/><ref name=Romero_et_al>{{cite journal |author=A Romero, MF Potter, DA Potter, KF Haynes |title=Insecticide Resistance in the Bed Bug: A Factor in the Pestâs Sudden Resurgence? |journal=Journal of medical entomology |volume=22 |issue=2 |pages=175â178 |year=2007 |pmid=|doi=10.1603/0022-2585(2007)44[175:IRITBB]2.0.CO;2 |url=http://www.thermal-remediation.com/users/thermal_remediation/files/Insecticide%20Resistance%20in%20the%20Bed%20Bug%20-%20A%20Factor%20in%20the%20Pests%20Sudden%20Resurgence.pdf |accessdate=2010-09-17 |issn=0022-2585}}</ref> Bed bugs have been known as human parasites for thousands of years.<ref name=JAMA2009/>
The name "bed bug" is derived from the insect's preferred habitat of houses and especially beds or other areas where people sleep. Bed bugs, though not strictly nocturnal, are mainly active at night and are capable of feeding unnoticed on their [[Host (biology)|host]]s. They have however been known by a variety of names, including wall louse, mahogany flat, crimson rambler, heavy dragoon, chinche and redcoat.<ref name=EncycEntomV1>{{Cite book |last = Capinera | first =John L. |title = Encyclopedia of Entomology, Volume 1 (2nd ed.) |publisher = Springer | location = |date = 17 Sep 2008 |pages = 405â417 |isbn = 1402062427 }} (Article: "Bed Bugs (Hemiptera: Cimicidae: ''Cimex'' spp.", Dini Miller, Virginia Tech University, VA</ref> {{TOC limit|3}}
==Description== ===Physical=== Adult bed bugs are light brown to reddish-brown, flattened, oval shaped and have no hind wings but front wings are vestigial and reduced to pad-like structures. Bed bugs have segmented abdomens with microscopic hairs that give them a banded appearance. Adults grow to 4â5 mm in length and 1.5â3 mm wide. Newly hatched [[Nymph (biology)|nymphs]] are translucent, lighter in colour and become browner as they [[ecdysis|moult]] and reach [[sexual maturity|maturity]]. Bed bugs may be mistaken for other insects such as [[booklice]] and [[carpet beetles]], or vice-versa.
Bed bugs use [[pheromones]] and [[kairomones]] to communicate regarding nesting locations, feeding and reproduction.
The life span of bed bugs varies by species and is also dependent on feeding.
Bed bugs can survive a wide range of temperatures and atmospheric compositions. Below {{convert|16.1|C|F}}, adults enter semi-hibernation and can survive longer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.augustineexterminators.com/galleryDetail.asp?gallery_id=26 |title=Augustine Exterminators |publisher=Augustine Exterminators |date= |accessdate=2010-09-01}}</ref> Bed bugs can survive for at least five days at {{convert|-10|C|F}} but will die after 15 minutes of exposure to {{convert|-32|C|F}}.<ref name="birc.org">IPM Practitioner, XXIX(3/4), March/April 2007 http://www.birc.org/MarApril2007.pdf</ref> They show high [[desiccation tolerance]], surviving low humidity and a 35â40 Â°C range even with loss of one-third of body weight; earlier life stages are more susceptible to drying out than later ones.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1 = Benoit | first1 = J. B. |last2 = del Grosso | first2 = N. |last3 = Yoder | first3 = J. A. |last4 = Denlinger | first4 = D. L. |title = Resistance to dehydration between bouts of blood feeding in the bed bug, Cimex lectularius, is enhanced by water conservation, aggregation, and quiescence |journal = [[American Journal of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene]] | volume = 76 | issue = 5 | pages = 987â993 |year = 2007 |url = http://www.ajtmh.org/cgi/content/full/76/5/987 | pmid = 17488928 | issn = 0002-9637 |accessdate = 27 May 2010 }}</ref> The thermal death point for ''C. lectularius'' is high: {{convert|45|C|F}}, and all stages of life are killed by 7 minutes of exposure to {{convert|46|C|F}}.<ref name=birc.org>{{Cite journal |last = Quarles | first = William |title = Bed Bugs Bounce Back |journal = IPM Practitioner | volume = 24 | issue = 3/4 | pages = 1â8 |publisher = Bio-Integral Resource Center |location = Berkeley, CA |date = March 2007 |url = http://www.birc.org/MarApril2007.pdf |format = PDF | accessdate = 27 May 2010 }}</ref> Bed bugs apparently cannot survive high concentrations of [[carbon dioxide]] for very long; exposure to nearly pure nitrogen atmospheres, however, appears to have relatively little effect even after 72 hours.<ref name=herrmannetal> {{Cite conference |last1 = Herrmann | first1 = J. |last2 = Adler | first2 = C. |last3 = Hoffmann | first3 = G. |last4 = Reichmuth | first4 = C. |title = Efficacy of controlled atmospheres on ''Cimex lectularius'' (L.) ===Feeding habits=== [[File:11739 lores.jpg|thumb|left|Scanning electron micrograph (SEM) of ''Cimex lectularius'', digitally colorized with the insectâs skin-piercing mouthparts highlighted in purple and red.]] Bed bugs are obligatory [[hematophagy|hematophagous]] (bloodsucking) insects. Most species feed on humans only when other prey are unavailable.<ref>{{cite web |last = Storey | first = Malcom |title = CIMICIDAE (bed bugs) |work = BioImages: The Virtual Field-Guide (UK) |publisher = bioimages.org.uk |url = http://www.bioimages.org.uk/html/t159942.htm |accessdate = 27 May 2010 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} </ref><ref name="Lance A. Durden 2002, p. 80">{{Cite book |last = Mullen | first = Gary R. | last2 = Durden | last1 = Lance A. |title = Medical and Veterinary Entomology, Second Edition |publisher = Academic Press | location = |date = 8 May 2009 |page = 80 |isbn = 0123725003 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title = Family CIMICIDAE |work = Australian Biological Resources Study: Australian Faunal Directory |publisher = Department of the Environment, Water, Heritage and the Arts (Australia) |year = 2008 |url = http://www.environment.gov.au/biodiversity/abrs/online-resources/fauna/afd/taxa/CIMICIDAE |accessdate = 27 May 2010 }} </ref> Bed bugs are attracted to their hosts primarily by [[carbon dioxide]], secondarily by warmth, and also by certain chemicals.<ref name=anderson09>{{Cite journal |title = A carbon dioxide, heat and chemical lure trap for the bed bug, Cimex lectularius |url = http://www.insect-interceptor.com/anderson.pdf|year = 2009 |journal = [[Medical and Veterinary Entomology]] | pages = 99â105 | volume = 23 | issue = 2 |last1 = Anderson | first1 = J.F. |last2 = Ferrandino | first2 = F.J. |last3 = McKnight | first3 = S. |last4 = Nolen | first4 = J. |last5 = Miller | first5 = J. |doi = 10.1111/j.1365-2915.2008.00790.x |accessdate = 2010-05-27 |postscript = <!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. --> }}</ref>
A bed bug pierces the skin of its host with what is called a stylet fascicle. This is a unit composed of the maxillae and mandibles which have been modified into elongate shapes from a basic, ancestral style. The right and left maxillary stylets are connected at their midline and a section at the centerline forms a large food canal and a smaller salivary canal. The entire maxillary and mandibular bundle penetrates the skin. The tips of the right and left maxillary stylets are not the same: the right is hook-like and curved, the left straight. The right and left mandibular stylets extend along the outer sides of their respective maxillary stylets and do not reach anywhere near the tip of the fused maxillary stylets. The stylets are retained in a groove in the labium and during feeding they are freed from the groove as the jointed labium is bent or folded out of the way: its tip never enters the wound. The mandibular stylet tips have small teeth and through alternately moving these stylets back and forth, the insect cuts a path through tissue for the maxillary bundle to reach an appropriate sized blood vessel. Feeding by sucking for about three to five minutes or more, the bug then withdraws the stylet bundle from the feeding position and retracts it back into the labial groove, folds the entire unit back under the head, and returns to its hiding place.<ref name=mednewstoday>{{cite web |title = What Are Bed Bugs? How To Kill Bed Bugs |work = Medical News Today | publisher = MediLexicon International Ltd |date = 20 Jul 2009 |url = http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/158065.php |accessdate = May 27, 2010 }}</ref> It takes between five to ten minutes for a bed bug to become completely engorged with blood.â<ref>{{cite journal | author = Thomas I., Kihiczak G. G., Schwartz R. A. | year = 2004 | title = Bed bug bites: a review | url = | journal = International Journal of Dermatology | volume = 43 | issue = 6| pages = 430â433 | doi = 10.1111/j.1365-4632.2004.02115.x | pmid = 15186224 }}</ref>
Although bed bugs can live for a year without feeding,<ref>{{Cite journal |last = Loye | first = Jenella E. |title = The life history and ecology of the cliff swallow bug, ''Oeciacus vicarius'' (Hemiptera : Cimicidae) |journal = Ent med. et Parasitol | publisher = Cah. This paper reports an abandoned swallow colony with ''[[Oeciacus vicarius]]'' surviving three consecutive years. However, that does not preclude the availability of other species (e.g., bats, other mammals, other birds) to fall back on for occasional feeding.</ref> they normally try to feed every five to ten days. In cold weather, bed bugs can live for about a year; at temperatures more conducive to activity and feeding, about 5 months.<ref name=Boase2001>{{Cite journal |title = Bedbugs â back from the brink |year = 2001 | pages = 159â162 | volume = 12 | issue = 4 |last = Boase | first = C. |journal = Pesticide Outlook |url = http://www.rsc.org/delivery/_ArticleLinking/DisplayArticleForFree.cfm?doi=b106301b |doi = 10.1039/b106301b | accessdate = 2010-05-27 |postscript = <!-- Bot inserted parameter. At the 57th Annual Meeting of the [[Entomological Society of America]] in 2009, newer generations of pesticide-resistant bed bugs in Virginia were reported to survive only two months without feeding.<ref name=diydetector>{{cite journal |last = Milius | first = Susan |title = Do-it-yourself bed-bug detector |work = Science News | publisher = Society for Science and the Public |date = 16 Jan 2010 | volume = 177 | issue = 2 | page = 88 |url = http://www.sciencenews.org/view/generic/id/51188/title/Do-it-yourself_bed-bug_detector |accessdate = 27 May 2010 }} citing {{Cite journal |last = Polanco-PinzÃ³n | first = Andrea | coauthors = et al. |title = Survivorship and growth potential of modern bed bug populations (''Cimex lectularius'') in the United States |journal = Conference proceedings of 57th Annual Meeting |publisher = Entomological Society of America |year = 2009 }}</ref>

===Reproduction=== [[File:Traumatic insemination 1 edit1.jpg|thumb|left|A bed bug (''Cimex lectularius'') [[Traumatic insemination|traumatically inseminates]] another]] All bed bugs [[Mating|mate]] by [[traumatic insemination]].<ref name=bioofbedbug/><ref name="carayon1959">Carayon, J. 1959 InsÃ©mination par âspermalÃ¨geâ et cordon conducteur de spermatozoids chez Stricticimex brevispinosus Usinger (Heteroptera, Cimicidae). Rev. Zool. Bot. Afr. 60, 81â104.</ref> Female bed bugs possess a [[reproductive tract]] that functions during [[oviposition]], but the male doesn't use this tract for [[insemination|sperm insemination]].<ref name=bioofbedbug/> Instead, the male pierces the female's [[abdomen]] with his hypodermic genitalia and [[ejaculation|ejaculates]] into the body cavity. In all bed bug species except ''Primicimex cavernis,'' sperm are injected into the mesospermalege,<ref name=bioofbedbug/> a component of the [[spermalege]],<ref name=bioofbedbug/> a secondary genital structure that reduces the wounding and immunological costs of traumatic insemination.<ref name=Morrow>{{cite journal | author = Morrow E. H., Arnqvist G. | year = 2003 | title = Costly traumatic insemination and a female counter-adaptation in bed bugs | url = | journal = Proceedings of the Royal Society B | volume = 270 | issue = 1531| pages = 2377â2381 | doi = 10.1098/rspb.2003.2514 | pmid = 14667354 | pmc = 1691516 }}</ref><ref name=Reinhardt2003>{{cite journal | author = Reinhardt K., Naylor R., Siva-Jothy M. T. | year = 2003 | title = Reducing a cost of traumatic insemination: female bedbugs evolve a unique organ | url = | journal = Proceedings of the Royal Society B | volume = 270 | issue = 1531| pages = 2371â2375 | doi = 10.1098/rspb.2003.2515 | pmid = 14667353 | pmc = 1691512 }}</ref><ref name=Ryne/> Injected sperm travel via the haemolymph (blood) to [[female sperm storage|sperm storage]] structures called seminal conceptacles, with fertilisation eventually taking place at the [[ovaries]].<ref name=Reinhardt2003/>
Male bed bugs sometimes attempt to mate with other males and pierce the latter in the abdomen.<ref>"[http://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/08/opinion/08berenbaum.html This Bedbug's Life]", ''[[The New York Times]]'', 7 August 2010.</ref> This behaviour occurs because [[sexual attraction]] in bed bugs is based primarily on size, and males will mount any freshly fed partner regardless of sex.<ref name=Harari>{{cite journal | author = Harari A., Brockman H. J., Landholt P. J. | year = 2000 | title = Intrasexual mounting in the beetle Diaprepes abbreviatus (L.) | url = | journal = Proceedings of the Royal Society B | volume = 267 | issue = 1457| pages = 2071â2079 | doi = 10.1098/rspb.2000.1251 | pmid = 11416911 | pmc = 1690776 }}</ref> The "bed bug alarm pheromone" consists of (''E'')-2-octenal and (''E'')-2-hexenal. It is released when a bed bug is disturbed, as during an attack by a predator. A 2009 study demonstrated that the alarm pheromone is also released by male bed bugs to repel other males who attempt to mate with them.<ref name=Ryne>Ryne, C. In press. "Homosexual interactions in bed bugs: Alarm pheromones as male recognition signals." ''Animal Behaviour''. doi: 10.1016/j.anbehav.2009.09.033 Cited in Cited in ''Science News'', November 21st, 2009; Vol.176 #11 (p. 13) "Scent of alarm identifies male bed bugs" by Susan Milius. http://www.sciencenews.org/view/generic/id/48927/title/Scent_of_alarm_identifies_male__bed_bugs</ref>
''C. lectularius'' and ''C. hemipterus'' will mate with each other given the opportunity, but the eggs then produced are usually sterile. In a 1988 study, 1 egg out of 479 was fertile and resulted in a hybrid, ''C. hemipterus'' Ã ''lectularius''.<ref>{{Cite journal |last = Newberry | first = K. |title = Production of a hybrid between the bedbugs ''Cimex hemipterus'' and ''Cimex lectularius'' |journal = [[Medical and Veterinary Entomology]] |volume = 2 | issue = 3 | pages = 297â300 |publisher = The Royal Entomological Society | location = |year = 1988 | month = July |doi = 10.1111/j.1365-2915.1988.tb00199.x | pmid=2980186}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last1 = Walpole | first1 = Debra E. | last2 = Newberry | first2 = K. |title = A field study of mating between two species of bedbug in northern KwaZulu, South Africa |journal = [[Medical and Veterinary Entomology]] |volume = 2 | issue = 3 | pages = 293â296 |publisher = The Royal Entomological Society | location = |year = 1988 | month = July |doi = 10.1111/j.1365-2915.1988.tb00198.x | pmid=2980185}}</ref>
===Life stages=== Bed bugs have six life stages (five immature and an adult stage).<ref>[http://www.euro.who.int/__data/assets/pdf_file/0011/98426/E91435.pdf] p.136</ref> They will shed their skins through a molting process ([[ecdysis]]) throughout multiple stages of their lives. The discarded outer shells look like clear, empty exoskeletons of the bugs themselves. Bed bugs must molt six times before becoming fertile adults.

==Infestation== [[File:Bedbug bites.jpg|thumb|A side of a face showing red blotchy marks covering much of it.]] {{Main|Bed bug infestation}} Bed bugs can cause a number of health effects including skin rashes, psychological effects and allergic symptoms.<ref name=GP2009>{{cite journal |author=Doggett SL, Russell R |title=Bed bugs â What the GP needs to know |journal=Aust Fam Physician |volume=38 |issue=11 |pages=880â4 |year=2009 |month=November |pmid=19893834 |doi= |url=}}</ref> They are able to be infected by at least 28 human pathogens, but no study has clearly found that the insect is able to transmit the pathogen to a human being.<ref>Kolb, A., et al. "Bedbugs." Dermatologic Therapy 22.4 (2009): 347-352. CAB Abstracts. EBSCO. Web. 5 Dec. 2010.</ref> Bed bug bites or cimicosis may lead to a range of skin manifestations from no visible effects to prominent blisters.<ref name="Andrews">{{cite book |author=James, William D.; Berger, Timothy G.; et al. |title=Andrews' Diseases of the Skin: clinical Dermatology |publisher=Saunders Elsevier |location= |year=2006 |pages= |isbn=0-7216-2921-0 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}}</ref> Diagnosis involves both finding bed bugs and the occurrence of compatible symptoms.<ref name=GP2009/> Treatment involves the elimination of the insect but is otherwise symptomatic.<ref name=GP2009/> They have been found with methicillin-resistant ''Staphylococcus aureus'' [[MRSA]]<ref>Meredith Melnick Thought Bed Bugs Were Bad? Try Bed Bugs With MRSA. TIME. Thursday, May 12, 2011 http://healthland.time.com/2011/05/12/thought-bed-bugs-were-bad-try-bed-bugs-with-mrsa/</ref> and with [[vancomycin]]-resistant ''Enterococcus faecium'' ([[Vancomycin-resistant enterococcus|VRE]]) but the significance of this is still unknown.<ref>Daniel J. DeNoon Do Bedbugs Spread MRSA? Drug-Resistant Bacteria Cultured From Bedbugs. WebMD. http://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/news/20110511/do-bedbugs-spread-mrsa</ref>
===Cause=== Dwellings can become infested with bed bugs in a variety of ways, from: *Bugs and eggs that "hitchhiked in" on pets,<ref name="Waldvogel">Waldvogel, M., C Apperson. 2006 " Bed Bugs." http://www.ces.ncsu.edu/depts/ent/notes/Urban/bedbugs.htm 21 November 2008</ref> or on clothing and luggage *Infested items (such as furniture or clothing) brought in *Nearby dwellings or infested items, if there are easy routes (through duct work or false ceilings) *Wild animals (such as bats or birds)<ref name="UKY">{{cite web |publisher = University of Kentucky College of Agriculture |title = BED BUGS |last1 = Potter | first1 = Michael F. |url = http://www.ca.uky.edu/entomology/entfacts/ef636.asp |accessdate = 27 June2010 }}</ref><ref name="avianadvice.uark.edu">Steelman, C.D. 2000. Biology and control of bed bugs, Cimex lectularius, in poultry houses. Avian Advice 2: 10,15. [http://www.avianadvice.uark.edu/AA%20PDFs/avian_advice2no2.pdf]</ref> *People visiting from a source of infestation; bed bugs, like roaches, are transferred by clothing, luggage, or a person's body.
===Detection=== [[File:Bedbug with eggs.jpg|thumb|An engorged female bed bug (''Cimex lectularius'') with eggs, discovered in the screw hole of a wooden bed frame]] Bed bugs are elusive and usually nocturnal, which can make them hard to spot. They often lodge unnoticed in dark crevices, and eggs can be nestled in fabric seams. Aside from bite symptoms, signs include fecal spots, blood smears on sheets, and molts.
Bed bugs can be found singly, but often congregate once established. They usually remain close to hosts, commonly in or near beds or couches. Harborage areas can vary greatly, however, including luggage, vehicles, furniture and bedside clutter. Bed bugs may also nest near animals that have nested within a dwelling, such as bats, birds,<ref name="avianadvice.uark.edu"/> or [[rodents]]. The eggs of bed bugs are found in similar places where the bed bugs themselves are found, and are attached to surfaces by a sticky substance.
Attractant devices for detection use heat and/or [[carbon dioxide]].<ref name=diydetector/>{{Better source|date=August 2011}}
[[File:BedbugSniffingDog.jpg|thumb|Bed bug detection dog in New York]]
Bed bugs can be detected by their characteristic smell of cilantro, coriander, almonds or over-ripe raspberries. [[Bed bug detection dogs]] are trained to pinpoint infestations, with a possible accuracy rate of 97.5%, based upon tests conducted under controlled conditions by researchers.<ref name="birc.org"/><ref>{{cite web |last1 = Pfiester | first1 = Margie |last2 = Koehler | first2 = Philip G. |last3 = Pereira| first3 = Roberto M. |title = Ability of Bed Bug-Detecting Canines to Locate Live Bed Bugs and Viable Bed Bug Eggs |publisher = Entomological Society of America | year = 2008 | month = Aug |url = http://www.bioone.org/doi/abs/10.1603/0022-0493%282008%29101%5B1389%3AAOBBCT%5D2.0.CO%3B2?journalCode=ecen#FN1 |accessdate = 26 Aug 2010 }}</ref> The success rates in these tests may not reflect real world success rates of a pest companiesâ dogs, operating with many more variables in the field.<ref name=nytimes>Buckley, Cara, "Doubts Rise on Bedbug-Sniffing Dogs", ''[[The New York Times (New York)|The New York Times]]'' of New York, New York, p 1, November 12, 2010</ref> Dog detection can often occur in minutes where a pest control practitioner might need an hour. In the United States, about 100 dogs are used to find bed bugs as of mid-2009.<ref name=advocate>{{Juliano, Michael C., "Dogs don't let the bed bugs bite", ''[[The Advocate (Stamford)|The Advocate]]'' of Stamford, Connecticut, p 1, August 21, 2009}}</ref> A few companies are experimenting with high speed gas chromatography to detect bed bugs and other insect vermin.
===Management=== {{main|Bed bug control techniques}}
Eradication of bed bugs frequently requires a combination of [[pesticide]] and non-pesticide approaches.<ref name=JAMA2009>{{Cite journal |author=Jerome Goddard & Richard deShazo |year=2009 |title=Bed bugs (''Cimex lectularius'') and clinical consequences of their bites |journal=[[Journal of the American Medical Association]] |url=http://jama.ama-assn.org/cgi/content/short/301/13/1358 |volume=301 |issue=13 |pages=1358â1366 |doi=10.1001/jama.2009.405 |pmid=19336711}}</ref><ref name="Kolb2009"/> Pesticides that have historically been found to be effective include: [[pyrethroid]]s, [[dichlorvos]] and [[malathion]].<ref name=Kolb2009/> Resistance to pesticides has increased significantly over time and there are concerns of [[Health effects of pesticides|negative health effects]] from their use.<ref name=JAMA2009/> Mechanical approaches such as vacuuming up the insects and heat treating or wrapping mattresses have been recommended.<ref name=JAMA2009/>
The [[carbamate]] insecticide [[propoxur]] is highly toxic to bed bugs, but in the United States the [[US Environmental Protection Agency|Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)]] has been reluctant to approve such an indoor use because of its potential toxicity to children after chronic exposure.<ref>[http://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/05/opinion/05sun3.html?ref=opinion New York Times. In Search of a Bedbug Solution.] Published: September 4, 2010.</ref>
===Predators=== Natural enemies of bed bugs include the [[masked hunter]] (also known as "masked bed bug hunter"),<ref>{{cite web |last = Hahn | first = Jeffrey |title = Masked hunters |work = Yard & Garden Briefs |publisher = University of Minnesota Extension Service: Yard & Garden Clinic |date = November 1999 |url = http://www.extension.umn.edu/yardandgarden/ygbriefs/e608maskedhunter.html |accessdate = 27 May 2010 }}</ref> [[cockroach]]es,<ref>Encyclopedia Americana, 1996 ed., v. 3, p. 413</ref> [[ant]]s, [[spider]]s (particularly ''[[Thanatus flavidus]]''), [[mite]]s and [[centipede]]s. The [[Pharaoh ant]]'s (''Monomorium pharaonis'') [[venom]] is lethal to bed bugs. [[Biological pest control]] is not very practical for eliminating bed bugs from human dwellings.<ref name="birc.org"/>
==Epidemiology== {{Main|Epidemiology of bed bugs}} [[Bed bugs]] occur around the world.<ref name=Heu09>{{Cite journal |title = Bed bugs, leeches and hookworm larvae in the skin | pmid=19362691 |year = 2009 |last1 = Heukelbach |first1 = J |last2 = Hengge |first2 = UR |volume = 27 |issue = 3 |pages = 285â90 |doi = 10.1016/j.clindermatol.2008.10.008 |journal = Clinics in dermatology |postscript = <!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}}}} pmid 19362691</ref> Rates of infestations in [[developed countries]], while decreasing from the 1930s to the 1980s, have increased dramatically since the 1980s.<ref name="JAMA2009"/><ref name="Kolb2009"/><ref name=Heu09/> Previously, they were common in the [[developing world]], but rare in the developed world.<ref name=Kolb2009/> The increase in the developed world may have been caused by increased international travel, resistance to [[insecticides]], and the use of new pest-control methods that do not affect bed bugs.<ref name="Romero_et_al"/><ref name="owen">{{cite web |last = Owen | first = James |title = Bloodthirsty Bedbugs Stage Comeback in U.S., Europe |work = National Geographic News |publisher = National Geographic |date = 13 May 2004 |url = http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2004/05/0513_040513_bedbugs.html |accessdate = 31 May 2010 }}</ref> The fall in bed bug populations after the 1930s in the developed world is believed to be partly due to the use of [[DDT]] to kill [[cockroaches]].<ref name=Nurse09>{{cite journal | pmid = 19233933 | doi=10.1177/1059840509331438 | volume=25 | issue=2 | title=Bedbugs: an equal opportunist and cosmopolitan creature | year=2009 | month=April | author=Krause-Parello CA, Sciscione P | journal=J Sch Nurs | pages=126â32}}</ref> The invention of the [[vacuum cleaner]] and simplification of furniture design may have also played a role.<ref name=Nurse09/> Others believe it might simply be the cyclical nature of the organism.<ref>[http://www.euro.who.int/__data/assets/pdf_file/0011/98426/E91435.pdf] p.131</ref>
The common bed bug (''Cimex lectularius'') is the species best adapted to human environments. It is found in [[temperate]] climates throughout the world. Other species include ''[[Cimex hemipterus]]'', found in [[tropics|tropical regions]], which also infests [[poultry]] and [[bat]]s, and ''[[Leptocimex boueti]]'', found in the tropics of [[West Africa]] and South America, which infests bats and humans. ''[[Cimex pilosellus]]'' and ''[[Cimex pipistrella]]'' primarily infest [[bat]]s, while ''[[Haematosiphon inodora]]'', a species of North America, primarily infests poultry.<ref>{{cite web |last1 = Cranshaw | first1 = W.S. |last2 = Camper | first2 = M. |last3 = Peairs | first3 = F.B. |title = Bat Bugs and Bed Bugs |publisher = Colorado State University Extension | year = 2009 | month = Feb |url = http://www.ext.colostate.edu/PUBS/INSECT/05574.html |accessdate = 27 May 2010 }} </ref>
==History== [[File:Parts of Bed-Bug.jpg|thumb|An 1860 engraving of parts of a bed bug. A. Intestines.âB. Antenna of the Male.âC Eye.âD. Haustellum, or Sucker, closed.âE. Side view of Sucker.âF. Under Part of Head.âG. Under Lip.âGG. Hair of the Tube, and outside Cases.âH. Egg-Bag.âI. Worm emerging from the Eggs]]
''C. lectularius'' may have originated in the Middle East, in [[caves]] inhabited by [[bat]]s and humans.<ref name="Lance A. Durden 2002, p. 80"/>
Bed bugs were mentioned in ancient Greece as early as 400 BC, and were later mentioned by [[Aristotle]]. [[Pliny's Natural History|Pliny's ''Natural History'']], first published circa 77 AD in Rome, claimed bed bugs had medicinal value in treating ailments such as snake bites and ear infections. (Belief in the medicinal use of bed bugs persisted until at least the 18th century, when [[Guettard]] recommended their use in the treatment of [[hysteria]].<ref>William Smith and Charles Anthon, ''A dictionary of Greek and Roman antiquities'', 1847, pp. 252-253 http://books.google.com/books?id=41oMAAAAYAAJ&dq=cimex&source=gbs_navlinks_s</ref>) Bed bugs were first mentioned in Germany in the 11th century, in France in the 13th century and in England in 1583,<ref name="Lance A. Durden 2002, p. 80"/> though they remained rare in England until 1670. Some in the 18th century believed bed bugs had been brought to London with supplies of wood to rebuild the city after the [[Great Fire of London]] (1666). [[Giovanni Antonio Scopoli]] noted their presence in [[Carniola]] (roughly equivalent to present-day Slovenia) in the 18th century.<ref>"That soon after the Fire of London, in some of the new-built Houses they were observ'd to appear, and were never noted to have been seen in the old, tho' they were then so few, as to be little taken notice of; yet as they were only seen in Firr-Timber, 'twas conjectured they were then first brought to ''England'' in them; of which most of the new Houses were partly built, instead of the good Oak destroy'd in the old." John Southall, ''A Treatise of Buggs'' [sic], pp. 16-17. http://www.archive.org/details/atreatisebuggss00soutgoog</ref><ref>"According to Scopoli's 2nd work (loc. cit.), found in Carniola and adjoining regions. According to Linnaeus' 2nd work on exotic insects (loc. cit.), before the era of health, already in Europe, seldom observed in England before 1670." Johann Friedrich Wolff and Johann Philip Wolff, ''Icones Cimicum descriptionibus illustratae'', fourth fascicle (1804), p. 127. http://www.archive.org/details/iconescimicumdes00wolf</ref>

Dusts have been used to ward off insects from grain storage for centuries, including "plant ash, lime, dolomite, certain types of soil, and [[diatomaceous earth]] (DE) or Kieselguhr".<ref name=hillde/> Of these, diatomaceous earth in particular has seen a revival as a nontoxic (when in amorphous form) residual pesticide for bed bug abatement. Insects exposed to diatomaceous earth may take several days to die.<ref name=hillde>{{Cite journal |last = Hill | first = Stuart B. |title = Diatomaceous Earth: A Non Toxic Pesticide |journal = Macdonald J. |volume = 47 | issue = 2 | pages = 14â42 | year = 1986 | month = May |publisher = Macdonald College | location = Ste-Anne de Bellevue, QC |url = http://eap.mcgill.ca/publications/eap4.htm |accessdate = 26 May 2010 }}</ref>
Basket-work panels were put around beds and shaken out in the morning, in the UK and in France in the 19th century. Scattering leaves of plants with microscopic hooked hairs around a bed at night, then sweeping them up in the morning and burning them, was a technique reportedly used in southern Rhodesia and in the Balkans.<ref name=Boase2001>{{Cite journal |title = Bedbugs - back from the brink |year = 2001 | pages = 159â162 | volume = 12 | issue = 4 |last = Boase | first = C. |journal = Pesticide Outlook |url = http://www.rsc.org/delivery/_ArticleLinking/DisplayArticleForFree.cfm?doi=b106301b |doi = 10.1039/b106301b | accessdate = 2010-05-27 |postscript = <!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. --> }}</ref>
Prior to the mid-twentieth century, bed bugs were very common. According to a report by the [[UK Ministry of Health]], in 1933 there were many areas where all the houses had some degree of bed bug infestation.<ref name="boase">{{Cite journal |url = http://scholar.google.com/scholar_alerts?view_op=create_alert_options |year = 2004 | month = April |last = Boase | first = Clive J. |title = Bed-bugs â reclaiming our cities |journal = Biologist | pages = 1â4 | volume = 51 |accessdate = 2010-06-07 |postscript = <!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. --> }} </ref>
Bed bugs were a serious problem during [[World War II]]. [[Douglas MacArthur|General MacArthur]] commented that bed bugs are the "greatest nuisance insect problem ... at bases in the U.S"<ref>http://www.dtic.mil/cgi-bin/GetTRDoc?AD=ADA506261&Location=U2&doc=GetTRDoc.pdf#page=23</ref>
With the arrival of potent [[pesticides]], famously [[DDT]] in the 1940s, bed bugs almost disappeared in Western countries.<ref name=newsweek0910>{{cite web |url=http://www.newsweek.com/2010/09/08/conservatives-blame-environmentalists-for-bedbugs.html |author=[[Newsweek]]| title=The Politics of Bedbugs|date=September 8, 2010 |accessdate=October 28, 2010}}</ref> However, bed bug infestations have resurged in recent years, for reasons which are not clear, but contributing factors may be complacency, increased resistance, bans on pesticides and increased international travel.<ref name=newsweek0910/> The current wave of bed bug infestations across America has spawned an industry for bed bug prevention, eradication and the reporting of infestations.{{citation needed|date=October 2010}}
==Society and culture== The saying "Good night, sleep tight, don't let the bed bugs bite." is common for parents to say to young children before they go to sleep.<ref>Berg, Rebecca. "Bed Bugs: The Pesticide Dilemma." Journal of Environmental Health 72.10 (2010): 32-35. Academic Search Premier. . Web. 30 Nov. 2010.</ref>
